New Records: The Rangers homered in 16 straight postseason games, a record.
Eovaldi became the first pitcher to win five starts in one postseason.
Key Match Events: Marcus Semien hit a home run in the ninth inning of Game 5, clinching the World Series for the Rangers.
Seager hit a changeup off the end of his bat, sending the ball squirting into left field for a single, breaking up Gallen's no-hitter in the seventh inning of Game 5.
Pre-Game Insights: General Manager Chris Young wanted a baseball team with an old soul, a player-centric band of brothers in an era when data analysts and 'high-performance' specialists can outnumber the players and seize much of the physical space of the clubhouse.
Young pulled Bruce Bochy, 68, off his recliner in Nashville to manage after a three-year hiatus.
Post-Match Reflections: Marcus Semien said, 'They mean everything to me. This is why I play this game. I show up to win the World Series and to play for them. I want them to have a better life than me.'
Damien Semien said, 'It is surreal. That's what got me. It is surreal.'
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Rangers won the World Series in their 63rd season, the seventh-longest drought in World Series history.
The Rangers spent $889.9 million on free agents the past two offseasons.
Others: Chris Young became only the third person to win the World Series as a player and as a general manager.
